post_title: [Weekly Megathread] Markets and Value Stock Ideas, Week of March 11, 2024
post_body:
What stocks are on your radar this week?

What's in the news that's affecting the market?

Celebrate your successes, rue your losses, or just chat with your fellow Value redditors!

Take everything here with a grain of salt! We suggest checking other users' posting/commenting history before following advice or stock recommendations.  Watch out for shill accounts that pump the same stock all over Reddit, or have many posts/comments deleted in other investing subreddits. Stay safe!

*(New Weekly Megathreads are posted every Monday at 0600 GMT.)*

post_title: [Weekly Megathread] Markets and Value Stock Ideas, Week of March 11, 2024
comment:
I own just 3 companies in my portfolio: STRT, CLPR, and TPL. 

STRT: no debt, current assets are worth the mcap, almost all properties are owned and value based on 1990‚Äôs purchase prices so NAV doesn‚Äôt reflect value. 2 activists (gabelli and gates), finally a management change and hopefully a board change to start unlocking value. They kind of started with the same of one division. 

CLPR; earnings were today. NOI of $80mill and once their next development is complete, along with full tax abatement for Flatbush  NOI will be closer to $90-100mill for 2024 FY.  5% cap rate on NOI puts PPE at 1.9-2bill in value. Debt is fixed and worth 1.2bill, walk away with 700mill on a 200 mill mcap stock all while collecting a 7-8% dividend that‚Äôs tax free since they are running a loss and most of it converts to returned capital.

TPL:  1mill acres of Texas land locked up in this trust all leased to oil giants and collects a nice royalty each year to buy back stock and pay a dividend. As long as management doesn‚Äôt mess it up with their new stock split, it‚Äôs a long term win if you can get your hands on any shares that is, very low volume and ~$1500 share price

post_title: Canadian Solar Inc CSIQ. What am I missing?
post_body:
Based on the 2023 full year earnings released a few days ago and the last closing price, you would pay 1.26 billion USD on a company generating a revenue of 7.6 billion USD and a net profit of 274 million USD activating in a sector with potential.
The balance sheet looks healthy having a current liquidity indicator above 1 and an equity ratio of 31%.
For 2024 they expect a revenue between 8.5-9.5 billion USD. Margins are expected to improve, but if the net profit margin of 2023 would be applied to the more pessimistic expectation of 8.5 billion USD, the net profit would be 306 million USD. In this case the P/E being 4.
Also, an additional reason for confidence is a recent 500 million USD investment from BlackRock.

What am I missing?

post_title: Canadian Solar Inc CSIQ. What am I missing?
comment:
I looked at this a while back and did think it was cheap however one risk is geopolitics. It's a Canadian company with almost all of its production in China. 

I believe they are making a plant in the USA now, and may be incentivised by US subsidies but I can't recall.

post_title: Canadian Solar Inc CSIQ. What am I missing?
comment: They and their peers are under investigation by homeland security.

post_title: Canadian Solar Inc CSIQ. What am I missing?
comment: Agree and it‚Äôs undervalued. The thing that institutional investors want to see is if they will start buying back shares or paying dividend otherwise the stock price will be irrelevant to their business performance

post_title: Canadian Solar Inc CSIQ. What am I missing?
comment:
Canadian Solar is one of the biggest, most established and respected makers of solar photovoltaic modules. However, there is not a ton of differentiation between the Tier 1 manufacturers. Solar modules are priced at about 10% of what they were 10-15 years ago, so yes, a 90% price drop. The market is headed for a glut, too many module makers. On top of this, there is always the risk of more tariffs being put up to prevent their import into the US or the EU; there are always a ton of politics in the energy business, solar is no exception. Given the above, I would be very cautious, especially re differentiation and tariffs. Source: self, worked in the solar business for many years.
Edit: despite the name, Canadian Solar is a Chinese company.

post_title: Canadian Solar Inc CSIQ. What am I missing?
comment: Don‚Äôt follow this company directly, but Solar module pricing come down. Production in China is a big risk and less valuable for domestic content 45x credits in the IRA. Whole renewables sector looks pretty cheap but is correlated with rates.

post_title: Canadian Solar Inc CSIQ. What am I missing?
comment:
No glaring red flags but some industry wide risks to consider for future profitability:

- geopolitics of energy manufacture + import/export
- recent decline in YoY revenue growth
- low profit margin business (3.6%) and stagnating demand (for now)
- current ratio of 1 
- average ROA in this industry is low, CSIQ is low single digits

And they don‚Äôt pay dividends or buyback stock. So you‚Äôre at the mercy of the stock price. If the business has a couple bad years you‚Äôve made no money lol

post_title: Berkshire Bought Back About $2.3 Billion in Stock - Barron's on MSN
post_body:
[https://www.msn.com/en-us/money/topstocks/berkshire-bought-back-about-23-billion-in-stock/ar-BB1jYwLc](https://www.msn.com/en-us/money/topstocks/berkshire-bought-back-about-23-billion-in-stock/ar-BB1jYwLc)   
  
Story by Andrew Bary  
  
Berkshire Hathaway bought back about $2.3 billion in stock in the first quarter through March 6, based on a Barron‚Äôs calculation from information in the company‚Äôs proxy statement released late Friday.  
  
The company repurchased about 3,800 Class A shares (with Class B stock buybacks converted to an equivalent amount of Class A shares) from year-end 2023 through March 6.  
  
The $2.3 billion of repurchases marks a pickup from the $2.2 billion of stock that Berkshire repurchased in the fourth quarter and could mean $3 billion or more of buybacks for the current quarter if the pace of repurchases continues at the rate of the first two months of the year.  
  
Most of the buybacks in the quarter occurred from Feb. 13 to March 6, with Barron‚Äôs estimating that total at around $1.7 billion with about $600 million repurchased in the first six weeks of the quarter.  
Investors watch the pace of Berkshire‚Äôs buybacks as an indication of whether Buffett views the stock as cheaply valued since he determines the pace of repurchases and has said repeatedly that he is price conscious.  
  
Berkshire stock has been strong this year with the Class A and B shares up about 14% against a roughly 7.5% total return for the S&P 500 index. The Class A stock finished Friday at $618,133, up 0.9%, while the Class B shares ended at $408.13, up 0.3%  
  
The proxy also discloses that Greg Abel, the likely successor to CEO Warren Buffett, earned just over $20 million in total compensation last year, up from $19 million in 2022.  
  
Abel, a Berkshire vice chairman, heads the company‚Äôs vast non-insurance operations. Ajit Jain, who oversees the company‚Äôs insurance businesses, also earned just over $20 million last year. Buffett, who determines their pay, has compensated them equally since they were elevated to their current positions in 2018.  
  
Berkshire continues to operate differently from other big companies on executive pay.  
  
For starters, Buffett is paid a salary of $100,000 a year with no bonus‚Äîa level of compensation he has received for over 35 years. The proxy states that he doesn‚Äôt want an increase in pay.  
  
He may be the only major CEO who reimburses the company for minor items such as phone calls and postage that are personal in nature. He reimbursed Berkshire $50,000 for those incidental expenses in 2023, in keeping with payments in past years.  
  
Berkshire spent over $300,000 on Buffett‚Äôs personal security last year, which is counted as compensation. But that is a fraction of companies such as Meta Platforms spend on their CEO security.  
  
Buffett pays for his own personal jet travel on NetJets, a Berkhsire company, and the company doesn‚Äôt pay for cars or country club dues for executives.  
  
Buffett hates parting with Berkshire Hathaway stock, viewing every share as precious, and doesn‚Äôt grant stock compensation to executives or any employees. The company states emphatically in the proxy: ‚ÄúBerkshire never intends to use Berkshire stock in compensating employees.‚Äù  
  
Berkshire lets Buffett set the compensation for Abel and Jain, and the proxy states the factors Buffett uses ‚Äútypically are subjective.‚Äù There are no incomprehensible formulas like there are at most public companies. And Berkshire doesn‚Äôt use compensation consultants in setting executive pay.  
  
Both Buffett and Charlie Munger, the Berkshire vice chairman who died at 99 in late 2023, dislike consultants of all kinds. Munger once said that he would rather ‚Äúthrow an asp down my shirt front‚Äù than hire one.  
  
Buffett once said that if Berkshire uses pay consultants after his death, he will rise from his grave in anger. Their view has been that companies use pay consultants to inflate executive compensation.

post_title: Berkshire Bought Back About $2.3 Billion in Stock - Barron's on MSN
comment: I wonder if the buybacks are becoming more a lack of available options than a true vote of confidence that the current price is low.

post_title: Berkshire Bought Back About $2.3 Billion in Stock - Barron's on MSN

post_title: Berkshire Bought Back About $2.3 Billion in Stock - Barron's on MSN
comment: Since starting the buyback program in 2018, they have paid $75 billion for shares that are now worth $128 billion (these figures are not inclusive of the latest buybacks). I‚Äôd say that‚Äôs a damn good outcome for a buy back program

post_title: Berkshire Bought Back About $2.3 Billion in Stock - Barron's on MSN
comment: Warren Buffett wrote in the 2022 annual report (page 6) that he only buys back the shares if the price is low enough (he used the term *value-accretive prices*) to benefit the remaining shareholders.  Looking at repurchase activity for the last 19 reported months (ending December 2023), he seems to be favoring buy backs of BRK.A over BRK.B - further concentrating the voting power.

post_title: Berkshire Bought Back About $2.3 Billion in Stock - Barron's on MSN
comment: Buffet needs to but businesses in the $100 billion range to have any significant effect on earnings, and there are not too many bargains at that price. He does buy smaller businesses that complement existing ones.

post_title: Berkshire Bought Back About $2.3 Billion in Stock - Barron's on MSN
comment:
Don't forget the huge privately-held companies that are still around.  At the 2022 annual meeting, I heard reliable scuttlebutt that Warren had the chance to buy Rolex, but that the price was more than he wanted to pay.  I also read that Pilot Flying J was the fifth largest private company in the US.

I think that there is a very good chance that, going forward, Berkshire Hathaway will always maintain enough cash available to quickly do a deal with private owners (to avoid bidding wars and seller's remorse).

post_title: Berkshire Bought Back About $2.3 Billion in Stock - Barron's on MSN
comment: I agree.  My understanding is that at one point, in the 1980's, Warren Buffett had a list of all the shareholders and tracked when his friends/family sold shares.

post_title: Berkshire Bought Back About $2.3 Billion in Stock - Barron's on MSN
comment: I think that it is very likely.  One of the articles that I read said that she talked to Warren before deciding to make the donation.

post_title: Berkshire Bought Back About $2.3 Billion in Stock - Barron's on MSN
comment:
Timing is kind of important here. $75B put in the S&P 500 on January 1st 2018 is now worth $160B.

At some point, I wouldn't mind if Warren/Greg just started buying the S&P 500 with excess cash instead of trying to beat the market. With the no dividend policy, anyone with a tax bracket above the corporate rate would still come out ahead.

post_title: Berkshire Bought Back About $2.3 Billion in Stock - Barron's on MSN
comment: Yeah, my point was that his "30%" below intrinsic value that he talked about at some point in the past is probably more like 10% these days, with lots of cash and nothing to buy. 10% is still value-accretive, but not what his standards used to be.

post_title: Berkshire Bought Back About $2.3 Billion in Stock - Barron's on MSN
comment: Rolex is a unique foundation structured organization deeply tied to the community and Wilsdorf heirs. I seriously doubt he would have had an opportunity to acquire it.

post_title: Berkshire Bought Back About $2.3 Billion in Stock - Barron's on MSN
comment: BRKs buy backs was not a lump some. This is the equivalent of a DCA between then and now of $75B in S&P 500. BRK continues to out perform the S&P.

post_title: Berkshire Bought Back About $2.3 Billion in Stock - Barron's on MSN
comment: I think it‚Äôs important that Buffett frames a successful buyback program as a dollar in buybacks creating more than a dollar in value. If you‚Äôre going to look to the S&P at every tick, you‚Äôre better off just owning the index then..

post_title: Berkshire Bought Back About $2.3 Billion in Stock - Barron's on MSN
comment: Don't forget about the 1% tax on repurchases that Biden wants to push to 4%.

post_title: Berkshire Bought Back About $2.3 Billion in Stock - Barron's on MSN
comment: He could be selling cash secured puts on BRK.A that generate income and only purchasing when assigned which would effectively reduce the cost of the share. Option premiums were great even on stable stocks recently.

post_title: Berkshire Bought Back About $2.3 Billion in Stock - Barron's on MSN
comment: Good point

post_title: Berkshire Bought Back About $2.3 Billion in Stock - Barron's on MSN
comment:
If we aren't beating the S&P 500 over 5+ year time-frames with our capital allocation, we should stop trying to beat the market and join it. Of course not every tick, but my standard for buybacks is the S&P 500 over long time periods, otherwise buy VOO or pay me a dividend to buy VOO.

I'm not saying Buffett made a mistake here, but I am saying the standard isn't a nominal return of 1%. The standard has to be the market.

post_title: Berkshire Bought Back About $2.3 Billion in Stock - Barron's on MSN
comment:
I'm fine with a 4% tax on buybacks, I'm sure Buffett is too. Unless your effective capital gains tax is below 4%, it's still a much cheaper way to return capital to shareholders vs dividends, assuming the stock is at or below intrinsic value. And unlike dividends, the owners still get to choose when to pay the capital gains taxes.

Remember, if you have ordinary income, dividends have their own tax, PLUS they push your income into a higher tax bracket. A dollar of dividends might have a 15% tax  plus push a dollar of income from the 24% to 32% bracket, making the effective tax on that dividend 23%. In that specific case, 4% on buybacks seems like a great deal, allowing me to sell some BRK at the time of my choosing.

post_title: Berkshire Bought Back About $2.3 Billion in Stock - Barron's on MSN
comment: As the guy pointed out below, your comparison wasn‚Äôt apples to apples, and the difference is much narrower than initially appears, as the money was invested unevenly over a five year period with Berkshire and day 1 in the s&p

post_title: Berkshire Bought Back About $2.3 Billion in Stock - Barron's on MSN
comment:
>Timing is kind of important here

That's why I led with this sentence. Sorry that read as ambiguous.

post_title: Berkshire Bought Back About $2.3 Billion in Stock - Barron's on MSN
comment:
Perhaps so. From Buffett's 1983 letter though...

>We feel noble intentions should be checked periodically against results. We test the wisdom of retaining earnings by assessing whether retention, over time, delivers shareholders at least $1 of market value for each $1 retained. To date, this test has been met. We will continue to apply it on a five-year rolling basis. As our net worth grows, it is more difficult to use retained earnings wisely.

Perhaps Buffett means nominal dollars here, but that seems silly to me.

While five years is not a long time, but the previous five years had COVID in it. I've got triples and doubles all over the place from March 2020.

post_title: Berkshire Bought Back About $2.3 Billion in Stock - Barron's on MSN
comment: Ideally you need to look at full economic cycles since Berkshire is a value type stock while SP500 has been more growth oriented recently. I mean, arguably we are still in a 15 year economic cycle.

post_title: Debt in current liabilities PayPal
post_body:
I'm currently doing a dcf valuation on PayPal and I need to calculate the net working capital of PayPal to calculate the FCFF. But I need to exclude debt in the current liabilitie number, but what is the debt of PayPal here:

Current liabilities:  
Accounts payable $197   
Funds payable and amounts due to customers $38,841   
Accrued expenses and other current liabilities $3,755   
Income taxes payable $236   
Total current liabilities $43,029

post_title: Debt in current liabilities PayPal
comment:
Why do you have to calculate it by level of accuracy and not materiality?

If cost > income = net profit margin was negative.

That meant for every $1 revenue - they lost money. 

And that means your free cash flow is negative. 

Without even having to calculate it.

post_title: Debt in current liabilities PayPal
comment: You‚Äôre thinking too hard on this lol

post_title: Debt in current liabilities PayPal
comment:
None of those items are debt. 

Funds payable and amounts due customers should be ignored for working capital purposes, however. So should the inverse in the liabilities section. Customer flows are not working capital.

post_title: Debt in current liabilities PayPal
comment: Waste of time doing DCF on financial companies.

post_title: Debt in current liabilities PayPal
comment:
There is no long-term debt coming due in the current liabilities here, so I suspect there is no adjustment to make.

As others have said, you may be focusing too much on the procedure and not enough on the fundamental business and accounting concepts underlying valuation. I think a lot of us want to start learning by doing and hew toward DCF valuations for that reason. Firms tend to use them to enforce consistency and in-house process, and corporate finance courses teach them, but they are highly sensitive to initial assumptions and their precision and seeming quantitative rigour can encourage overconfidence in the results.

I have noticed most self-professed value investors, after some time investing, end up rarely if ever using DCFs.

post_title: top ten signs a business is valuable
post_body:
Figured I'd start a list.

These are my notes from 10 years of studying stocks as a Wall Street analyst:

Operating leverage

Proprietary data

Embeddedness

Low cost of replication

Secular trend

Tuck-in acquisitions

Low cost of capital

Efficient capital use

Networks

Physical assets

If you want an explanation + walkthrough of what it looks like in financial statements, here's a video: [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=6IdzOKqAEgc](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=6IdzOKqAEgc)

Ps if you're looking for a course or educational resources on picking stocks, I can send you a free workshop that I put together.

Anything else I'm missing?

​

post_title: BTI - value play or trap?
post_body: The recent news of it divesting out of ITC and using the proceeds to fund buybacks and dividend increase is positive news, but the share price quickly dipped back. Will anything move the stock, or is BTI doomed to plateau??

post_title: BTI - value play or trap?
comment:
Well, at the end of the day it's a consumer staple. It will move, but not by much relative to everything else. It's a defensive play. As a defensive play you're fine with it not moving much (but also not moving much during downturns) while returning you that juicy dividend. It's a bonus if it goes up.

As I wrote in my [portfolio update post..](https://www.reddit.com/r/ValueInvesting/comments/1b8c8uo/portfolio_update_you_dont_need_big_tech_for_big/)

Cigarettes are on a decline, yes, but at a snails-pace. From 2019 to 2023 BTI cigarette sales have declined only about 3%. Meanwhile, alternative tobacco products like vaping have increased substantially. I believe the alternative tobacco products will not only replace lost cigarette revenue, but cause overall revenue to grow - at a snails pace, but still, it will grow. (Example: BTI Vapour products had 401mil in sales in 2019, and now it's at 1802mil).

The risk is that countries like the UK follow Australia (and Mexico..) in banning vapes. But there's a good chance they will only ban disposable vapes.

post_title: BTI - value play or trap?
comment:
Value traps by definition appear cheap while having continually deteriorating fundamentals. 

BTI doesn‚Äôt have deteriorating fundamentals. Cigarettes by volume will be in a steady decline but price increases will offset it.

post_title: BTI - value play or trap?
comment: I hold a good amount of BTI but it‚Äôs outside of my typical investment strategy. Basically, my mentality is that it‚Äôs essentially like holdings bonds, but with a higher yield and the potential for upside with even a modest re-rating of its dirt cheap valuation. It‚Äôll probably be the first thing I sell if I need to raise cash for a better opportunity that comes along.

post_title: BTI - value play or trap?
comment: People have been saying it‚Äôs the end of tobacco companies for decades. At the end of the day, they print cash and the dividend appears relatively safe. I don‚Äôt have a large position but it‚Äôs nice to collect a 10% dividend, and I expect some price appreciation when bond yields drop

post_title: BTI - value play or trap?
comment: BTI is ridiculously cheap.  Here we have a stock selling at \~6 PE which would imply the company is a value trap - but operating cash flow is growing at \~ [8% CAGR](https://userupload.gurufocus.com/1768980923627499520.png).  What am I missing?

post_title: BTI - value play or trap?
comment: The share price dipping back down is a good thing when they plan to do a buyback with that money. Last time they announced buybacks (2021?) the price shot up like 30-40%. That was alot of money down the toilet.

post_title: BTI - value play or trap?
comment: I buy this on the dips since even a small increase in price is all you need with the yield so high.

post_title: BTI - value play or trap?
comment: Both.

post_title: BTI - value play or trap?
comment: BTI is trading near fair market value - what is the argument for the price to move above fair value?

post_title: BTI - value play or trap?
comment:
Honestly? It can be both. 

They had to write off the accounting value of some of their cigarette brands resulting in a non-cash loss recently.

It's still printing cash but it's all still cigarette fuelled and therefore is highly legislatively vulnerable.

However their new generation products (NGPs) hit breakeven way ahead of schedule. But NGPs are not favourably viewed by many governments around the world, despite their potential health harm and public cost being way less than that of alcohol or obesity implicated foods. That's the "trap".

post_title: BTI - value play or trap?
comment: The problem of cigarette industry is there are no Mad Men to save them from competitions unlike alcohol industry. New generation products are the same since Juul got blow up, way too many competitions. I would say it is a good stock to hold if rates come down fast so the dividend will discount nicely push the stock up.

post_title: BTI - value play or trap?
comment: I am a fan of sinstockspapi on twitter

post_title: BTI - value play or trap?
comment:
Just reading about this Australia 'ban' now, and seems it would be more accurate to call it a control than a ban, and not sure to pass anyway.

I can't see any country wanting to drive people back to smoking. Well maybe Mexico, but not any developed country. The science really isn't on their side this time. 

However yes, do ban disposable vapes because they are targeted at young people and the takeup rates are high.

What I find strange is the valuation gap between BTI and PM. So I know that PM have the better portfolio in many ways, less reliant on combustibles, ahead of the game on alternatives, but still, the gap is massive, and I think it also reflects the US-Europe valuation gap, whereby European equities are secularly undervalued vs US equities, even if they do most of their business in the US. 

I think BTI is a great value play for those looking for 'good companies at great prices' as opposed to 'wonderful companies at fair prices'.

Also really adds to a portfolio in terms of defensive qualities as you described.

post_title: BTI - value play or trap?
comment: This is the correct way to view this stock. 100% agree with, don't own it but I've looked at it. This was my conclusion it's a defensive bond with some miniscule upside.

post_title: BTI - value play or trap?
comment: I do the same thing.

post_title: How I Benefited From ValueInvesting
post_body:
I studied finance in college and I currently work in book publishing at one of the Big 5 publishers, on the demand planning and inventory management end. Anyway, I started off my investing journey in late 2015 by going through an advisor. I have about 68% of my total funds invested in mutual funds, the largest holding being KNPAX, which has been very good.  
  
However, when 2020 came around I unloaded a lot of my savings in the market. Eventually, I asked him to buy a couple stocks instead of just the same mutual funds I was investing in. He explained that it would be cheaper for me to just do it on my own, so I did instead of him buying the stocks for me.   
I opened up my own brokerage acct and I did well, as anyone would at that time in mid 2020. I had a return of 89% in 2020, -1% in 2021, and -23% in 2022. But, in early 2023 I started consolidating my stock investments as I was overdiversified, I thought.  I, also, found Value Investing because I really didn‚Äôt have time to do research, and I figured I would look for adept, real individuals who were offering, what I believed to be, genuine financial and market analysis, and could defend their investment recommendations against the critics within the group. I have a good understanding of macroeconomics, financial statements, profitability, risk, etc. I have always believed in the fundamentals and value investing, but I am not suave enough and nor do I have the experience and time to make sound investments on my own, so I used this thread to guide my investments. I would look for investment recs in industries that I like(energy, healthcare, financial services, and so on), and if I liked the argument and investment pitch being made, I looked at the companies financials and gauged it as best I could  
I have invested in NMIH, PM, VNOM, CPLP, HSY, ECPG, MDT; I‚Äôm up on every one. I‚Äôve done relatively well, partly because of this thread. I am invested in 17 stocks altogether, but I was up 22% in 2023. This group is filled with a lot of good advice, I think. It‚Äôs been very helpful to me so far. (knock on wood).    
  
Just wanted to say thanks and to share,

post_title: How I Benefited From ValueInvesting
comment: Glad to see we all have benefited, the key learn and share your mistakes so others can learn not only from your ideas but also from mistakes

post_title: How I Benefited From ValueInvesting

post_title: "Revenge of the Nerds": Tweedy Browne paper on how Value investing has outperformed many indexes since q3 2020
"Revenge of the Nerds": Tweedy Browne paper on how Value investing has outperformed many indexes since q3 2020
comment:
Would be more informative if they picked 2019 as the start instead of 2020. Oil & gas majors got irrationally blown to hell after COVID and they are usually categorized as value, oil & gas majors largely reverted, hence value outperformed.

So is it really that value outperformed or just that oil & gas majors outperformed after their stocks crashed?

Edit: Oh god it's comparing value indices to growth indices, not value to total... that makes things even less informative since growth is largely comprised of digital/tech companies that got a huge temporary boost in stock prices, again, due to COVID.

post_title: "Revenge of the Nerds": Tweedy Browne paper on how Value investing has outperformed many indexes since q3 2020
comment: "Value" used in the context of academics or indexes¬†has nothing to do with value investing. It is literally just stocks that are trading at low multiples.

post_title: "Revenge of the Nerds": Tweedy Browne paper on how Value investing has outperformed many indexes since q3 2020
comment: Its mostly a function of interest rates.  As interest rate rise, the discount rates used for DCF calculation rise and this favors "value" as opposed to "growth".

post_title: "Revenge of the Nerds": Tweedy Browne paper on how Value investing has outperformed many indexes since q3 2020
comment: Unfortunately what you described in your last sentence is how many many people try to practice value investing in practice.
